posts.text: How to setup KVM/QEMU on Arch. I’m an Arch user, and now I want to setup an VM using KVM/Qemu. The VM shall use Arch OS as well and I have prepared the ISO file. Show me how to make it First of all, remember to disable your firewall! As it will affect the setup of networking in the VM To set up an Arch Linux virtual machine (VM) using KVM/QEMU, you can follow these steps. Here’s a detailed guide: Step 1: Ensure KVM/QEMU is Installed Install the necessary packages: 1sudo pacman -S qemu virt-manager libvirt edk2-ovmf dnsmasq bridge-utils Enable and start the libvirtd service: 1sudo systemctl enable --now libvirtd Verify that virtualization is supported: 1lscpu | grep Virtualization Ensure the output shows VT-x (Intel) or AMD-V (AMD). Add your user to the libvirt group to manage VMs without root: 1sudo usermod -aG libvirt $(whoami) Log out and log back in for this to take effect. Step 2: Prepare the Arch ISOEnsure you have the Arch ISO file ready. For example, suppose the file is at /home/username/Downloads/archlinux.iso. Step 3: Create a Virtual Machine Launch virt-manager: 1virt-manager This opens the Virtual Machine Manager GUI. Create a new VM: Click File → New Virtual Machine. Select Local install media (ISO image or CDROM) and click Forward. Choose Use ISO image, browse for your Arch Linux ISO, and click Forward. Assign resources: Allocate memory (RAM) and CPUs. For example: RAM: 2048 MB (2 GB) or more CPUs: 2 or more Click Forward. Set up storage: Choose Create a disk image for the virtual machine. Allocate disk space (e.g., 20 GB or more). Click Forward. Configure advanced options: Set Firmware to UEFI if desired (use edk2-ovmf for Arch). Review the configuration and click Finish to create the VM. Step 4: Boot the VM Start the VM: In virt-manager, select the VM and click Start. Follow the Arch Linux installation process: Boot from the ISO. Partition the virtual disk, configure the system, and install Arch as you would on a physical machine. Step 5: Network ConfigurationKVM uses NAT for network by default, allowing your VM to access the internet. If you need a bridged network for direct access to your local network, configure it in virt-manager under Network Interfaces. Optional: Configure the VM for Optimal Performance Install virtio drivers in the Arch VM: During installation, ensure the kernel has virtio modules enabled for better performance (e.g., virtio_blk, virtio_net). Enable SPICE or QXL for better graphics: In virt-manager, under Display, choose Spice and install the spice-vdagent package in the guest for clipboard and resolution integration. Let me know if you need guidance on a specific step or if you’d prefer a terminal-only setup! Ah I have ufw firewall in my host machine, will that affect? Yes, having ufw (Uncomplicated Firewall) enabled on your host machine can absolutely affect the VM’s ability to communicate with the network, especially when using NAT or bridge mode. By default, ufw blocks some types of traffic that are essential for virtual machine networking, including: DHCP traffic (UDP ports 67 and 68) for IP address assignment. DNS traffic (UDP port 53) for name resolution. NAT or bridge traffic between the VM and the host. To fix this, you need to adjust the ufw settings to allow the necessary traffic. Here’s how: Step 1: Identify the Problem Check if ufw is active: 1sudo ufw status If it says active, it is managing your network traffic. Test if disabling ufw temporarily resolves the issue: 1sudo ufw disable If the VM obtains an IP address after this, ufw is blocking critical traffic. Don’t leave ufw disabled permanently; adjust the rules instead. Step 2: Allow Necessary Traffic for NAT (virbr0)For NAT-based networking (default libvirt network): Allow traffic on the virbr0 interface: 12sudo ufw allow in on virbr0sudo ufw allow out on virbr0 Allow DHCP traffic: (not necessary) 12sudo ufw allow in on virbr0 to any port 67 proto udpsudo ufw allow out on virbr0 to any port 68 proto udp Allow DNS traffic: (not necessary) 12sudo ufw allow in on virbr0 to any port 53 proto udpsudo ufw allow out on virbr0 to any port 53 proto udp Reload ufw: 1sudo ufw reload Step 3: Allow Traffic for Bridge ModeFor bridge networking, you’ll need to allow traffic on the bridge interface (br0 or equivalent): Allow all traffic on the bridge interface: 12sudo ufw allow in on br0sudo ufw allow out on br0 Allow DHCP and DNS traffic: 1234sudo ufw allow in on br0 to any port 67 proto udpsudo ufw allow out on br0 to any port 68 proto udpsudo ufw allow in on br0 to any port 53 proto udpsudo ufw allow out on br0 to any port 53 proto udp Reload ufw: 1sudo ufw reload Step 4: Allow Forwarding for NATFor NAT-based networks, you also need to ensure that the host allows traffic to forward through the NAT interface: Edit the ufw configuration file: 1sudo nano /etc/default/ufw Find the line: 1DEFAULT_FORWARD_POLICY="DROP" Replace it with: 1DEFAULT_FORWARD_POLICY="ACCEPT" Allow forwarding for libvirt’s NAT traffic: 12sudo ufw route allow in on virbr0 out on enp3s0sudo ufw route allow out on enp3s0 in on virbr0 Reload ufw: 1sudo ufw reload Step 5: Test Connectivity Restart the VM and test again:12ping -c 3 8.8.8.8ping -c 3 archlinux.org Verify that the VM has received an IPv4 address:1ip addr show Step 6: Debug Further (if Needed) Check UFW Logs:To identify blocked traffic:12sudo ufw status verbosesudo journalctl -f | grep UFW Tailor the Rules:If logs show specific blocked traffic, adjust the rules to allow it. With these adjustments, ufw should no longer block the necessary traffic, and your VM should be able to access the network properly. Let me know if you need additional help!

posts.text: Use rclone with its local encryption feature enabled. It is a good solution for data backup. Generated by GPT and proved to be true: To use rclone crypt, you need to configure rclone to encrypt your files locally before uploading them to a cloud storage provider (such as Amazon S3, Google Drive, Dropbox, etc.). Here’s a step-by-step guide for setting up rclone crypt to encrypt and decrypt your data. Steps to Use rclone crypt1. Install rcloneIf you haven’t installed rclone yet, do so: On Arch Linux, you can install it via pacman: 1sudo pacman -S rclone For other platforms, follow the official installation guide. 2. Configure rclone for Your Cloud Provider (S3 Example)First, you need to configure rclone for your cloud storage service (e.g., Amazon S3). This process creates a remote in rclone that connects to your cloud storage. Run the following command: 1rclone config Choose n for a new remote. Give it a name (e.g., myS3). Select your cloud provider (e.g., for S3, choose 4 for Amazon S3). Enter the necessary configuration details (Access Key, Secret Key, region, etc.). Complete the setup. This will create a remote called myS3 that connects to your S3 bucket. 3. Set Up rclone CryptNow you’ll configure rclone crypt, which will encrypt the files before uploading them to the cloud. This encrypted remote will point to the S3 bucket you just set up. Run: 1rclone config Choose n for a new remote. Give it a name (e.g., myS3-encrypted). Select 8 for the crypt option (the encryption type). When asked for the remote to encrypt, enter the path to your S3 bucket (e.g., myS3:bucketname). rclone will ask how you want to encrypt filenames. You can choose: Standard (recommended): encrypts both file content and names. Obfuscated: only obfuscates filenames, keeping them human-readable. No encryption: only the file content is encrypted. rclone will then ask you to create an encryption password. Make sure to use a strong password. Optionally, you can set a password for directory name encryption. Complete the setup. You now have an encrypted remote called myS3-encrypted. Any files uploaded to this remote will be encrypted locally before uploading to S3. 4. Upload Files to the Encrypted RemoteOnce the encrypted remote is set up, you can use rclone commands to upload files to the encrypted S3 bucket. To upload files to the encrypted remote: 1rclone copy /path/to/local/files myS3-encrypted:/ Replace /path/to/local/files with the path to your local files. myS3-encrypted:/ is the root of your encrypted remote in the S3 bucket. 5. Access and Decrypt FilesTo download and decrypt the files from your encrypted remote: 1rclone copy myS3-encrypted:/ /path/to/local/directory This command will download and decrypt the files, storing them in /path/to/local/directory. 6. Automating SyncsYou can use rclone sync to automate file synchronization between your local machine and the encrypted remote: 1rclone sync /path/to/local/files myS3-encrypted:/ This will sync changes from your local directory to the encrypted S3 remote. Android SupportTo access the encrypted files on Android, you can: Use rclone in a terminal (via Termux). Install FolderSync or other apps supporting rclone, although this will not provide automatic decryption (you’ll need to manually decrypt using the same rclone setup). Example Commands Summary rclone config: Set up the remote and crypt remote. rclone copy /path/to/local/files myS3-encrypted:/: Upload encrypted files. rclone copy myS3-encrypted:/ /path/to/local/directory: Download and decrypt files. rclone sync /path/to/local/files myS3-encrypted:/: Sync encrypted files with your cloud storage. posts.text: By ChatGPT To configure a cron job, you’ll use the crontab command, which allows you to schedule tasks to run at specific intervals (e.g., every day, hour, or minute). Here’s how you can do it: Step 1: Open the Crontab FileTo create or edit cron jobs, run the following command: 1crontab -e This opens the crontab file for the current user in the default text editor (usually nano or vim). Step 2: Understanding the Crontab FormatEach line in the crontab file represents a scheduled job and follows this format: 1* * * * * /path/to/script.sh The five asterisks represent time fields (minute, hour, day of month, month, day of week), followed by the command or script to run. Here’s what each field represents: 1234567* * * * * command| | | | || | | | └── Day of the week (0 - 7) (Sunday=0 or 7)| | | └──── Month (1 - 12)| | └────── Day of the month (1 - 31)| └──────── Hour (0 - 23)└────────── Minute (0 - 59) Step 3: Adding a Cron JobLet’s say you want to run a backup script at 2 AM every day: 10 2 * * * /home/user/backup.sh This cron job will execute the script /home/user/backup.sh at 2:00 AM daily. Here are more examples: Every 5 minutes: 1*/5 * * * * /path/to/script.sh Every day at midnight: 10 0 * * * /path/to/script.sh Every Monday at 3:30 AM: 130 3 * * 1 /path/to/script.sh Every day at 2 PM in June: 10 14 * 6 * /path/to/script.sh Step 4: Save and ExitOnce you’ve added the desired cron jobs, save the file and exit the editor (Ctrl + O, Enter, Ctrl + X if using nano). Step 5: Verify the Cron JobAfter setting the cron job, you can verify if it’s successfully scheduled by running: 1crontab -l This will list all active cron jobs for the current user. Step 6: Logs and DebuggingCron logs can help you debug issues with cron jobs. On most Linux systems, you can find the cron logs in: 1/var/log/cron Or, you can check the system log: 1sudo journalctl -u cron Examples of Common Cron Jobs Run a script every day at 3 AM: 10 3 * * * /home/user/daily_backup.sh Run a script every Sunday at midnight: 10 0 * * 0 /home/user/weekly_report.sh Run a script every 10 minutes: 1*/10 * * * * /home/user/monitor_service.sh SummaryTo configure a cron job: Open crontab with crontab -e. Add a job using the correct time syntax. Save and exit. Verify it with crontab -l. Let me know if you need help with any specific cron job configuration!

posts.text: Vaultwarden is a lightweight, self-hosted password manager that is compatible with Bitwarden clients. It is designed as an efficient alternative to the official Bitwarden server, using fewer system resources while providing similar features like storing, managing, and sharing passwords securely. Vaultwarden can be run in a Docker container, making it easy to set up on personal servers or low-powered devices. It supports a wide range of Bitwarden clients, including browser extensions, mobile apps, and desktop apps, and can be extended with features like two-factor authentication and encrypted storage. Configuring Install it and run it using docker, according to the official tutorial Create new account, initialize the database and setup the password, etc. (Optional) Configure firewall using UFW or other tools to allow communication to it. Install the browser extension, mobile app for connection Restart the service using command like this to: disable registration of new users and invitation Enable auto restart port remapping 12345docker run -d --name vaultwarden --restart unless-stopped \ -e SIGNUPS_ALLOWED=false -e INVITATIONS_ALLOWED=false \-v ~/Stockroom/dataInUse/vw-data/:/data \-p 9010:80 \vaultwarden/server:latest Setup backup for the data folder, vw-data on the example above. Can follow this tutorial in the end For the usage in LAN, it is not necessary to setup HTTPS.For private use, using a Wireguard to setup a private network for all your devices can be a better choice. Backup tutorial Generated by GPT To sync your Vaultwarden data daily using rclone, you’ll need to set up an rclone configuration and then create a script that will run the sync command. Here’s how to do it step-by-step: Step 1: Install RcloneIf you haven’t already installed rclone, you can do so using the following command: 1sudo pacman -S rclone Step 2: Configure Rclone Run Rclone Config:Open a terminal and run: 1rclone config Create a New Remote: Type n to create a new remote. Give it a name (e.g., vaultwarden_backup). Choose the storage type you want to use (e.g., Google Drive, S3, etc.) and follow the prompts to configure it. You may need to authenticate with your cloud service. Test the Configuration:Once you’ve set up the remote, you can test it by running: 1rclone ls vaultwarden_backup: Replace vaultwarden_backup with the name you chose. Step 3: Create a Backup ScriptCreate a script that will perform the sync operation. Here’s a basic example of what the script might look like: Create a New Script File: 1nano ~/backup_vaultwarden.sh Add the Following Content: 12345678#!/bin/bash# Define the source and destinationSOURCE="/path/to/vaultwarden/data" # Adjust this pathDESTINATION="vaultwarden_backup:/path/to/destination" # Adjust this path# Perform the syncrclone sync "$SOURCE" "$DESTINATION" --progress --log-file=/path/to/logfile.log --log-level INFO Make sure to adjust the SOURCE and DESTINATION paths accordingly: SOURCE: This should be the path to your Vaultwarden data directory (often found inside your Docker container or where you mounted the volume). DESTINATION: This should be your configured rclone remote destination. Make the Script Executable: 1chmod +x ~/backup_vaultwarden.sh Step 4: Schedule the Script with CronTo run the backup script daily, you can add a cron job. Open the Crontab: 1crontab -e Add a New Cron Job: Add the following line to run the backup every day at 2 AM (adjust the time as needed): 10 2 * * * /bin/bash /home/yourusername/backup_vaultwarden.sh Make sure to replace /home/yourusername with your actual home directory path. Step 5: Verify the BackupAfter the first run, check the log file specified in the script to verify that the backup completed successfully. You can view it with: 1cat /path/to/logfile.log SummaryThis setup will allow you to sync your Vaultwarden data to a cloud storage solution of your choice every day using rclone. KDE Connect uses a combination of mDNS (Multicast DNS) and a D-Bus-based service discovery mechanism to find and connect with other devices on the same local network. Here’s how it works: How KDE Connect Finds Other Devices: mDNS for Discovery: KDE Connect broadcasts its presence over the local network using mDNS. This allows it to advertise itself and listen for other KDE Connect instances. When you start KDE Connect on your laptop or phone, it sends out multicast DNS packets to announce its service availability. This is how devices can discover each other without needing static IP addresses. D-Bus Communication: KDE Connect uses D-Bus, a message bus system that provides a way for inter-process communication. Devices communicate over D-Bus once they discover each other. When a device wants to connect to another, it uses the D-Bus API to establish the connection and initiate various actions (like sending notifications, sharing files, etc.). Authentication: When a new device is discovered, KDE Connect prompts you to approve the connection. This ensures that only devices you trust can connect to each other. Once authenticated, the devices can communicate securely over the local network. Benefits of Using KDE Connect: Cross-Platform: KDE Connect works on Linux, Android, and other platforms, allowing for seamless integration across devices. Multiple Features: Besides basic discovery, it offers features like file sharing, clipboard synchronization, remote control, and notification mirroring. No Internet Required: KDE Connect operates over the local network, so it doesn’t need an active internet connection for most features. Troubleshooting Discovery:If you’re having trouble discovering devices with KDE Connect, ensure that: Both devices are on the same local network. Firewalls or network settings aren’t blocking mDNS packets. You have KDE Connect running on both devices.

posts.slug: Wireguard for comm between Arch and Android

posts.excerpt: Build a wiregard communication between the Arch laptop and my Android phone. Following the instructions from ChatGPT, which I proved to work.
posts.text: Build a wiregard communication between the Arch laptop and my Android phone. Following the instructions from ChatGPT, which I proved to work. https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/WireGuard# From GPT: To set up a private network between your Arch Linux laptop and your Android phone within a large LAN, you can create a secure tunnel or virtual private network (VPN) to ensure only these two devices communicate directly, safely bypassing other potentially malicious devices. Here’s a simple approach: Option 1: WireGuard VPNWireGuard is a fast and modern VPN protocol that’s well-suited for creating a private network between your devices. On Arch Linux (Laptop): Install WireGuard: 1sudo pacman -S wireguard-tools Generate keys: 1wg genkey | tee privatekey | wg pubkey > publickey Configure WireGuard:Create a WireGuard configuration file (e.g., /etc/wireguard/wg0.conf): 12345678[Interface]PrivateKey = <your_laptop_private_key>Address = 10.0.0.1/24ListenPort = 51820[Peer]PublicKey = <your_phone_public_key>AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.2/32 Start the WireGuard interface: 1sudo wg-quick up wg0 Can also use other tools, as long as the Wireguard is supported. For example, the network manager from KDE does support Wireguard, so just configure it in the same way. On Android (Phone): Install the WireGuard app from the Play Store. Generate keys on the phone using the WireGuard app. Configure WireGuard on the phone: Add a new tunnel in the app and set the following details: Interface: Use your phone’s private key and set 10.0.0.2/24 as the IP. Peer: Set the laptop’s public key and Allowed IPs: 10.0.0.1/32. Endpoint: Your laptop’s LAN IP address with port 51820. Activate the tunnel in the WireGuard app. Now, the devices can communicate securely over this private network. You’re correct! In WireGuard, peers don’t automatically discover each other on a network without at least one side specifying an endpoint. WireGuard is a stateless, point-to-point VPN, so it relies on manually configuring endpoints to establish a connection between devices. Here’s how it works: Endpoint Role:The endpoint is essentially the “address” where one device (peer) will attempt to contact the other. Without an endpoint, the peers won’t know where to send the initial packets. Why You Need an Endpoint on at Least One Side: WireGuard doesn’t broadcast or discover peers like other networking protocols (e.g., DHCP). Both devices remain silent until one side initiates communication by sending a packet to the other’s IP address and port. At least one side needs the endpoint of the other peer (IP address and port) to start the handshake. So, in your case where the Android phone and the Arch Linux laptop are on the same LAN, here’s how you should approach it: Solutions for Your Case: Configure Endpoint on One Device: You can set up the endpoint on one side (either the laptop or the phone). If you configure the endpoint on the laptop, it will initiate the connection to the phone, and vice versa. For instance, if your phone has a static IP on the LAN (e.g., 192.168.1.10), you can configure the endpoint on the laptop to point to the phone. Example (Laptop-side configuration): 1234[Peer]PublicKey = <phone_public_key>AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.2/32Endpoint = 192.168.1.10:51820 # Phone's local IP and WireGuard port Configure Endpoint on Both Devices: To ensure both devices can initiate the connection (especially useful if either device is mobile and changes networks frequently), you can configure endpoints on both sides. For example, on your laptop, set the phone’s LAN IP as the endpoint, and on the phone, set the laptop’s LAN IP as the endpoint. Example (Android-side configuration): 1234[Peer]PublicKey = <laptop_public_key>AllowedIPs = 10.0.0.1/32Endpoint = 192.168.1.5:51820 # Laptop's local IP and WireGuard port Dynamic IPs (No Static Endpoint): If either the phone or the laptop has a changing IP (e.g., on different networks): You can configure a dynamic DNS (DDNS) service to ensure the device’s endpoint is always updated, even if the IP changes. This is helpful for devices that are frequently on different networks. Otherwise, you’d need to update the endpoint manually each time the IP changes. Summary: Endpoint is needed for initial communication: At least one device must know the other’s IP and port (via the endpoint) to initiate a connection. Best Practice: Configure an endpoint on one side, and optionally on both sides for more flexibility.

posts.title: Use rclone to mount cloud storage
posts.slug: Use rclone to mount cloud storage
posts.excerpt: rclone is a versatile tool for syncing and mounting cloud storage, supporting almost all cloud providers, including google cloud, onedrive, webdav, S3, etc. Following these steps to use rclone to mount cloud storage:
posts.text: rclone is a versatile tool for syncing and mounting cloud storage, supporting almost all cloud providers, including google cloud, onedrive, webdav, S3, etc. Following these steps to use rclone to mount cloud storage: Add configFirst decide the cloud service provider and follow the config example for connection establish. You can find all supported CSP and protocols here: https://rclone.org/#providers After setting up, you can use rclone ls to check if the connection is ready. MountUse S3 for example: 1234mkdir ~/my-s3-bucketrclone mount remote-name:bucket-name ~/my-s3-bucketor rclone mount --daemon remote-name:bucket-name ~/my-s3-bucket Additional information from ChatGPT:When you use rclone to mount an S3 bucket, it behaves like a regular filesystem. This means that any changes you make in the mounted directory (like adding, deleting, or modifying files) will be automatically reflected in the S3 storage. However, there are a few points to keep in mind: How rclone mount Works Real-Time Synchronization: Any file changes (create, update, delete) in the mounted directory are directly uploaded or modified in S3 in real time, as rclone handles the synchronization automatically while the mount is active. Cache Considerations: By default, rclone mount uses a caching mechanism to improve performance. You can control how caching works using various flags (like --vfs-cache-mode). For instance, you can use: --vfs-cache-mode writes to cache writes before sending them to S3. --vfs-cache-mode full to cache all file operations (reads, writes) locally. Unmounting: Before unmounting the S3 bucket, ensure all changes are flushed to avoid losing data. You can do this by ensuring that any pending operations are completed. Example of Mounting Mount the S3 Bucket:Here’s how you can mount your S3 bucket using rclone: 12mkdir ~/my-s3-bucketrclone mount remote-name:bucket-name ~/my-s3-bucket --vfs-cache-mode writes Access Files:You can then navigate to ~/my-s3-bucket and work with your files directly. Any changes you make will automatically sync to S3. Unmount the Bucket:To unmount, use: 1fusermount -u ~/my-s3-bucket Notes Performance: While rclone mount provides real-time syncing, it may not be as fast as accessing local files, especially if your internet connection is slow. Backup and Sync Options: For heavy workloads or critical data, consider using both mounting and scheduled syncs for added redundancy. Using rclone to mount your S3 bucket gives you the flexibility of a filesystem while automatically syncing your changes to the cloud. Auto mountYou can use one systemd.service to do this: You’re right! If you add rclone to /etc/fstab, it requires sudo (root) permissions to run during boot, but your rclone configuration is stored in your user directory (typically ~/.config/rclone/rclone.conf). This can lead to permission issues, since root won’t have access to your user’s configuration. Solutions:1. Use a systemd Service for Mounting (Recommended)This method avoids the need for root access to your user-specific rclone configuration, while still allowing automatic mounting at startup. Steps to Create a systemd Service: Create a systemd service file:Create a file in your user’s systemd directory (without needing sudo): 12mkdir -p ~/.config/systemd/usernano ~/.config/systemd/user/rclone-s3-mount.service Add the following content to the file: 1234567891011121314[Unit]Description=Rclone mount for S3 bucketAfter=network-online.targetWants=network-online.target[Service]Type=notifyExecStart=/usr/bin/rclone mount remote-name:bucket-name path/to/s3-bucket \ --config /home/YOUR_USER/.config/rclone/rclone.confExecStop=/bin/fusermount -u /mnt/s3-bucketRestart=always[Install]WantedBy=default.target Replace: remote-name:bucket-name with your actual remote and S3 bucket name. YOUR_USER with your username. Adjust the paths as necessary. Enable the service:Now that the service file is ready, enable it for your user: 1systemctl --user enable rclone-s3-mount.service Start the service:You can start the service immediately: 1systemctl --user start rclone-s3-mount.service Enable lingering to allow auto-start on boot:To ensure that systemd starts the service at boot, enable lingering for your user: 1sudo loginctl enable-linger YOUR_USER This ensures that rclone will mount the S3 bucket at startup, without needing root permissions or dealing with /etc/fstab. It also solves the problem of accessing your user’s rclone configuration file. 2. Move the rclone.conf File to a Location Root Can Access (Less Recommended)If you prefer sticking with /etc/fstab, you could move your rclone.conf file to a system-wide location, such as /etc/rclone/rclone.conf, which root can access. Then, update the configuration file path in /etc/fstab. Move the config file: 12sudo mkdir /etc/rclonesudo cp ~/.config/rclone/rclone.conf /etc/rclone/rclone.conf Edit /etc/fstab:Modify the rclone mount entry in /etc/fstab to reference the new config file path: 1rclone#remote-name:bucket-name /mnt/s3-bucket fuse rclone,config=/etc/rclone/rclone.conf,uid=1000,gid=1000,allow_other,umask=0022 0 0 Adjust permissions:Make sure the config file is readable by root: 1sudo chmod 644 /etc/rclone/rclone.conf Note: This approach exposes your credentials to a system-wide location, which may not be as secure as keeping the configuration in your user directory. ConclusionUsing a systemd service is the recommended approach because it maintains the security of your user-specific rclone configuration while still allowing the S3 bucket to be mounted automatically at startup.

posts.excerpt: Learn about how to use timeshift properly in case of scroll failure when using Arch
posts.text: Learn about how to use timeshift properly in case of scroll failure when using Arch If your system becomes unstable or unusable after a failed sudo pacman -Syu update, and you have a Timeshift snapshot, you can recover your system by restoring the snapshot. Here’s how you can do it: Step 1: Boot into a Live USB (if necessary)If your system is not booting, you’ll need to boot from a live USB. Create a Live USB if you don’t have one using a tool like Rufus or balenaEtcher. Boot from the Live USB and select the “Boot Arch Linux” option or any Linux distribution that supports Timeshift. Step 2: Install Timeshift on the Live USB Environment (if needed)If Timeshift is not available in the live environment, you’ll need to install it. Connect to the internet: 1sudo wifi-menu # or use another method to connect Install Timeshift: 1sudo pacman -S timeshift Step 3: Mount the Root FilesystemIf you booted into a live environment, you’ll need to mount your root filesystem where Timeshift snapshots are stored. Find your root partition: 1lsblk Look for the partition where your root filesystem (usually /dev/sdaX or /dev/nvme0n1pX) is located. Mount the root partition: 1sudo mount /dev/sdaX /mnt Replace /dev/sdaX with your actual root partition. Mount the boot partition (if you have a separate boot partition): 1sudo mount /dev/sdaY /mnt/boot Replace /dev/sdaY with your boot partition. Mount other essential filesystems: 123sudo mount --bind /dev /mnt/devsudo mount --bind /proc /mnt/procsudo mount --bind /sys /mnt/sys Step 4: Restore the Timeshift Snapshot Launch Timeshift:If you are in the live environment: 1sudo timeshift --gui If you are in your normal system (like if the system is bootable but unstable), you can run Timeshift normally: 1timeshift-launcher Select the snapshot you want to restore. Choose one from before the failed pacman -Syu update. Click “Restore” and follow the prompts. Timeshift will restore the selected snapshot, effectively rolling back your system to the state it was in when the snapshot was taken. Be sure to check the options to restore the bootloader if you believe it was affected. Step 5: Reboot Your System After the restoration process is complete, unmount the partitions if necessary: 123sudo umount /mnt/bootsudo umount /mnt/dev /mnt/proc /mnt/syssudo umount /mnt Reboot your system: 1sudo reboot Your system should now boot into the restored snapshot. Troubleshooting If the system still doesn’t boot correctly, make sure that the bootloader and essential files were restored properly. You may need to chroot into the system from the live environment and reinstall the bootloader if necessary. If Timeshift restores successfully but you still face issues, there might be a deeper problem unrelated to the update that needs additional troubleshooting. This process should help you recover your system to a previous working state using Timeshift after a failed system update.

posts.title: Add NTFS automount
posts.text: From ChatGPT: To automatically mount an NTFS disk on boot in Arch Linux, you can configure it by editing the /etc/fstab file. Here’s how you can do it: 1. Identify the NTFS Partition: First, you need to find the UUID or device name of the NTFS partition you want to mount. Use the following command: 1234 sudo blkid or sudo fdisk -l You should see output like: 1/dev/sda1: UUID="XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXX" TYPE="ntfs" PARTUUID="XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXX" Note down the UUID or the device name (e.g., /dev/sda1). 2. Install the Required NTFS Driver: Arch Linux requires the ntfs-3g package to mount NTFS partitions with read-write support. Install it with: 1sudo pacman -S ntfs-3g 3. Edit the /etc/fstab File: Open the /etc/fstab file with your preferred text editor: 1sudo nano /etc/fstab Add a new line for your NTFS partition using either the UUID or the device name. The syntax is: 1UUID=XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXX /mnt/your-mount-point ntfs-3g defaults 0 0 Alternatively, if you prefer to use the device name: 1/dev/sda1 /mnt/your-mount-point ntfs-3g defaults 0 0 Replace UUID=XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXX with your partition’s UUID or /dev/sda1 with your device name. Replace /mnt/your-mount-point with the directory where you want the partition to be mounted (you need to create this directory if it doesn’t exist). 4. Create the Mount Point (if necessary): If the mount point directory doesn’t exist, create it: 1sudo mkdir -p /mnt/your-mount-point 5. Test the Configuration: Test if the configuration works without rebooting: 1sudo mount -a If you don’t see any errors, the partition should now be mounted at the specified mount point. 6. Reboot and Verify: Reboot your system: 1sudo reboot After rebooting, check if the NTFS partition is automatically mounted by running: 1df -h You should see your NTFS partition listed. Example /etc/fstab Entry:Here’s what a complete line might look like in your /etc/fstab: 1UUID=XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXX /mnt/ntfsdisk ntfs-3g defaults 0 0 This setup will ensure your NTFS partition is automatically mounted at boot.

posts.text: Encounter some issues when using electron-based applications, and need to run them with some flags. Best way to create a new desktop entry for it. From GPT: Option 2 is the best choice How to enable electron-based application with Chinese input like fcitx5 ime, etc. --enable-wayland-ime seems to work as one experimental feature for now. Do not modify the original desktop entry directly, create a new one instead, or it will be overwritten when upgrading. To run Joplin with specific flags like --enable-wayland-ime by default every time you start the application, you have several options depending on how you prefer to configure this. Below are some common approaches: Option 1: Create a Wrapper ScriptYou can create a small script that automatically adds the flags whenever Joplin is launched. Create a script in your local bin directory: 12mkdir -p ~/.local/binnano ~/.local/bin/joplin Add the following content to the script: 12#!/bin/bash/usr/bin/joplin-desktop --enable-wayland-ime "$@" This script will run Joplin with the --enable-wayland-ime flag every time, while still allowing you to pass additional arguments ("$@"). Make the script executable: 1chmod +x ~/.local/bin/joplin Ensure ~/.local/bin is in your PATH. It typically is by default, but you can verify this by running: 1echo $PATH Now, when you type joplin in the terminal or launch it via an application menu, it will include the --enable-wayland-ime flag by default. Option 2: Modify the Desktop Entry (for Launching via Application Menu)If you primarily launch Joplin from your desktop environment’s application menu, you can modify the .desktop file to include the flags. Copy the existing Joplin desktop entry to your local applications directory: 12mkdir -p ~/.local/share/applicationscp /usr/share/applications/joplin.desktop ~/.local/share/applications/ Edit the copied file: 1nano ~/.local/share/applications/joplin.desktop Locate the Exec line and modify it to include the desired flags: 1Exec=joplin-desktop --enable-wayland-ime %U Save the file and exit. Now, whenever you launch Joplin from the application menu, it will automatically use the --enable-wayland-ime flag. Option 3: Use an Alias (for Terminal Launches)If you typically launch Joplin from the terminal, you can create an alias in your shell configuration file. Open your .bashrc (or .zshrc if you use zsh): 1nano ~/.bashrc Add the following line: 1alias joplin='joplin-desktop --enable-wayland-ime' Save the file and exit. Reload your shell configuration: 1source ~/.bashrc Now, typing joplin in the terminal will include the flag automatically. Summary Wrapper Script (Option 1): Flexible and works universally. Desktop Entry Modification (Option 2): Ideal if you use the application menu. Alias (Option 3): Quick solution for terminal launches. Choose the method that best fits your workflow.

posts.title: Set global environmental variables on session startup
posts.slug: Set global environmental variables on session star
posts.path: 2024/08/27/Set global environmental variables on session star/
posts.excerpt: I used Option3: Use Systemd User Environment Configuration
posts.text: I used Option3: Use Systemd User Environment Configuration If you prefer to set the MOZ_ENABLE_WAYLAND=1 environment variable globally, you can do this by configuring it in a way that it applies to your entire user session. Here’s a more detailed explanation of how to do this in Arch Linux. Option 1: Set the Variable in the User’s ~/.profileOne common way to set environment variables globally for your user is by adding them to ~/.profile. This file is sourced by various login shells and desktop environments when you log in. Open (or create) the ~/.profile file: 1nano ~/.profile Add the following line at the end of the file: 1export MOZ_ENABLE_WAYLAND=1 Save the file and exit. For the change to take effect, log out of your session and log back in, or you can apply it immediately with: 1source ~/.profile This method ensures that the environment variable is set whenever you log into your desktop environment, regardless of the shell you use. Option 2: Set the Variable in the ~/.bash_profileIf you’re using bash, another option is to set the environment variable in your ~/.bash_profile. This file is specifically for setting environment variables for login shells. Open the ~/.bash_profile file (create it if it doesn’t exist): 1nano ~/.bash_profile Add the following line: 1export MOZ_ENABLE_WAYLAND=1 Save the file and exit. Log out and log back in to apply the change, or run: 1source ~/.bash_profile This is effective if your desktop environment sources ~/.bash_profile when starting a session. Option 3: Use Systemd User Environment Configuration (Recommended for Modern Systems) [I used for my system]Systemd provides a cleaner and more reliable way to manage environment variables for user sessions. Create a new environment configuration file: 12mkdir -p ~/.config/environment.dnano ~/.config/environment.d/envvars.conf Add the following line: 1MOZ_ENABLE_WAYLAND=1 Save the file and exit. Reload the systemd user environment: 1systemctl --user daemon-reload Log out and log back in for the changes to take effect. This method is highly recommended for modern desktop environments (like KDE Plasma) because it’s designed to work seamlessly with systemd. Option 4: Set the Variable in /etc/environment (Applies to All Users)If you want to set the variable for all users on the system, you can do so in the /etc/environment file. Note that this requires root privileges. Edit the /etc/environment file: 1sudo nano /etc/environment Add the following line: 1MOZ_ENABLE_WAYLAND=1 Save the file and exit. Reboot your system or log out and log back in for the change to take effect. This method applies the environment variable globally across all users and sessions. Summary Single user, across all shells and desktop sessions: Use ~/.profile or ~/.bash_profile. Modern systemd-based approach: Use ~/.config/environment.d/envvars.conf. System-wide for all users: Use /etc/environment. For most users, Option 3 (systemd environment configuration) is the most robust and cleanest solution, especially for KDE Plasma or other modern desktop environments that rely heavily on systemd. I used Method 3: using environemt.d/envvars.conf To check the variable, using echo $VARIABLE_NAME Can also refer to this tutorial from Arch Wiki: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Environment_variables

posts.title: Check app in wayland or Xorg
posts.slug: Check app in wayland or Xorg
posts.excerpt: Using xprop works fine for me.
posts.text: Using xprop works fine for me. From ChatGPT: In Arch Linux with KDE Plasma, applications can run either under Wayland or Xorg, even if you’re using a Wayland session. To determine whether a specific application is running under Wayland or Xorg (via XWayland), you can follow these methods: Method 1: Using xpropThe xprop command works for applications running under Xorg (including those running under XWayland in a Wayland session). Run xprop in your terminal. Your cursor will turn into a crosshair. Click on the window of the application you want to inspect. If the application is running under XWayland, you’ll see output with the property _NET_WM_PID. This indicates it’s running under XWayland (and therefore Xorg-based). If it’s a Wayland native app, xprop will not work since it doesn’t interact with Wayland-native apps. Method 2: Checking the WAYLAND_DISPLAY Environment VariableYou can check whether an app is using Wayland by inspecting its environment variables: Find the process ID (PID) of the application: 1pidof <application-name> Use the grep command to check if the application is running under Wayland: 1cat /proc/$(pidof <application-name>)/environ | tr '\0' '\n' | grep WAYLAND_DISPLAY If WAYLAND_DISPLAY is present, the application is running natively under Wayland. If not, it is likely running under XWayland or Xorg. Method 3: Using xwininfo or xdotoolSimilar to xprop, both xwininfo and xdotool only work with X11/XWayland applications. If these commands detect the application, it’s running under XWayland. Run: 1xwininfo Or: 1xdotool search --name "<application-name>" If these commands successfully interact with the window, it’s an XWayland application. Otherwise, it’s native to Wayland. Method 4: Using KSysGuard or System MonitorIn KDE Plasma: Open System Monitor or KSysGuard. Find the application in the process list. Right-click the application and check its properties or command. If you see XWayland in the details, the app is running under XWayland. Summary If the app is visible via xprop, xwininfo, or xdotool, it is running under XWayland (and therefore Xorg). If the environment variable WAYLAND_DISPLAY is set, the app is running natively on Wayland. These methods should help you determine whether an app is using Wayland natively or is running under XWayland in your KDE Plasma environment. In practice using xprop works fine for me.

posts.title: Downgrading packages - ArchWiki
posts.excerpt: How to downgrade package of pacman or aur, which is not so convenient.
posts.text: How to downgrade package of pacman or aur, which is not so convenient. Refer to https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Downgrading_packages Before downgrading a single or multiple packages, consider why you wish to do so. If it is due to a bug, follow the bug reporting guidelines. I.e. search the Arch Linux Bugtracker for existing tasks and if there is none, add a new task. It is better to correct bugs, or at least warn other users of possible issues. Warning: Downgrading one package may require that its dependencies be downgraded as well. When the number of packages to downgrade is large, consider using a snapshot. See Arch Linux Archive#How to restore all packages to a specific date. Be careful with changes to configuration files and scripts. For now pacman will handle this for us, as long as we do not bypass its safeguards. If a downgrade involves a soname change, all dependencies may need downgrading or rebuilding too. Return to an earlier package versionUsing the pacman cache This only works if the old version has been installed previously. Not very useful to be honest If a package was installed at an earlier stage, and the pacman cache was not cleaned, install an earlier version from /var/cache/pacman/pkg/. This process will remove the current package and install the older version. Dependency changes will be handled, but pacman will not handle version conflicts. If a library or other package needs to be downgraded with the packages, please be aware that you will have to downgrade this package yourself as well. # pacman -U file:///var/cache/pacman/pkg/package-old_version.pkg.tar.type Note that type will be xz for older package builds, and zst for those following the 2020 change. Once the package is reverted, temporarily add it to the IgnorePkg section of pacman.conf, until the difficulty with the updated package is resolved. Downgrading the kernelIn case of issue with a new kernel, the Linux packages can be downgraded to the last working ones #Using the pacman cache. Go into the directory /var/cache/pacman/pkg and downgrade at least linux, linux-headers and any kernel modules. For example: # pacman -U file://linux-4.15.8-1-x86_64.pkg.tar.xz file://linux-headers-4.15.8-1-x86_64.pkg.tar.xz file://virtualbox-host-modules-arch-5.2.8-4-x86_64.pkg.tar.xz Tip: If you are unable to boot after a kernel update, you can downgrade the kernel chrooting into the system. Boot using an Arch Linux USB flash installation media and mount the partition where your system is installed to /mnt. If you have /boot or /var on separate partitions, also mount them to /mnt (e.g. mount /dev/sdc3 /mnt/boot). Then chroot into the system using: # arch-chroot /mnt Now you can go into the pacman cache directory and downgrade the Linux packages using the command indicated above. Once done, exit the chroot (with exit) and reboot. Arch Linux Archive Works only for official packages except AUR packages The Arch Linux Archive is a daily snapshot of the official repositories. It can be used to install a previous package version, or restore the system to an earlier date. Rebuild the packageIf the package is unavailable, find the correct PKGBUILD and rebuild it with makepkg. For packages from the official repositories, retrieve the PKGBUILD with ABS and change the software version. Alternatively, find the package on the Packages website, click “View Changes”, and navigate to the desired version. The necessary files can then be downloaded from the directory so that the package can be rebuilt. See also Arch build system#Using the pkgctl tool. Works for AUR packages, using git checkout [Hash Value] to change to a specific version and use makepkg -si to rebuild the package. Old AUR packages can be built by checking out an old commit in the AUR package Git repository. For pre-2015 AUR3 PKGBUILDs, see Arch User Repository#Git repositories for AUR3 packages. Automation Did not try, and should not try this unstable bash script I think… downgrade — A Bash script to downgrade one (or multiple) packages, by using the pacman cache or the Arch Linux Archive. See downgrade(8) for details. https://github.com/pbrisbin/downgrade || downgradeAUR Return from [testing] See Official repositories#Disabling testing repositories.

posts.title: Pacman -Syu save memory
posts.excerpt: Notice that when using pacman -Syu to scroll to latest, the memory will increases about 15G, most of which are occupied by pacman cache, which can be cleared to save memory resource if it is constrained.
posts.text: Notice that when using pacman -Syu to scroll to latest, the memory will increases about 15G, most of which are occupied by pacman cache, which can be cleared to save memory resource if it is constrained. Generated by ChatGPT If you find that running pacman -Syu frequently leads to installing a large number of packages, which consumes a significant amount of disk space and memory, there are a few strategies you can use to mitigate this issue in Arch Linux: 1. Optimize Mirrorlist Ensure that your mirrorlist is optimized to use the fastest and most up-to-date mirrors. You can use reflector to generate a new mirrorlist:12sudo pacman -S reflectorsudo reflector --country 'Your_Country' --age 6 --sort rate --save /etc/pacman.d/mirrorlist Replace 'Your_Country' with your actual country. This can help reduce the amount of data you need to download by connecting to the most up-to-date and fastest mirrors. 2. Enable Package Compression Enable package compression to reduce the size of the packages. Edit /etc/pacman.conf and find the Compression section. You can enable or configure the compression options to save space. 3. Partial Upgrades Although partial upgrades are generally not recommended in Arch, if the updates are too large, you could selectively update packages by running:1sudo pacman -Syu <package1> <package2> ... This allows you to update critical or frequently used packages instead of updating the entire system at once. 4. Use paccache to Clean Cache By default, pacman stores the last three versions of each package in /var/cache/pacman/pkg/. Over time, this cache can grow significantly. You can reduce its size using paccache:12sudo pacman -S pacman-contribsudo paccache -r This will remove all but the most recent three versions of each cached package. You can adjust the number by using the -k option (e.g., -k2 to keep only the last two versions). 5. Remove Unneeded Dependencies Sometimes, installed packages bring in dependencies that are no longer needed after a package is removed. You can clean up these orphaned packages with:1sudo pacman -Rns $(pacman -Qtdq) This removes unused dependencies that are not explicitly installed. 6. Regular Maintenance Regularly clean the system of old packages and dependencies: Clean the package cache:1sudo pacman -Sc or for a more aggressive cleaning:1sudo pacman -Scc Remove unneeded packages with:1sudo pacman -Rns $(pacman -Qdtq) 7. Check for Large Packages Identify large packages that you might not need or that can be replaced with lighter alternatives:1sudo pacman -Qdtq | xargs pacman -Qi | awk '/^Name/{name=$3}/^Installed Size/{print name, $4 $5}' | sort -k2 -h 8. Consider Using the NoExtract Option If there are packages with parts that you don’t need (e.g., documentation, optional features), you can use the NoExtract option in /etc/pacman.conf to skip installing certain files. 9. Upgrade Regularly Instead of upgrading sporadically, try to update your system more regularly. This will often result in smaller incremental updates. By implementing these strategies, you can reduce the amount of data you need to download and manage, and keep your Arch Linux system lean and efficient.

posts.title: Customize ydotool setting
posts.excerpt: ydotool (1.0.4-2) seems to failed to automatically enable the background service, thus I wrote this tutorial to automatically start the background service ydotoold.service.
posts.text: ydotool (1.0.4-2) seems to failed to automatically enable the background service, thus I wrote this tutorial to automatically start the background service ydotoold.service. Although there is one indeed useless service config file in /usr/lib/systemd/user/ydotool.service, it can not be called and enabled correctly, and ydotoold can not be executed by normal user without root permission and it should be able to access /dev/uinput. Therefore, I need to modify it and add it as one system service with sudo permission, by modifying the config file and move it to etc/systemd/system/ydotoold.service. (inspired by this blog ) To enhance the security I create one group for it and add the users that need to use it into that group, so that any other users can not use it. Here is the totorial generated by ChatGPT and I followed it. The issue may be related to how the ydotoold service is interpreting the --socket-own and --socket-mode parameters. The ydotoold might not be setting the socket ownership and mode correctly when run as a service. To troubleshoot and resolve this, we can take a few steps: Step 1: Verify Group and UserEnsure the group ydotoolgroup exists and includes the necessary users: Create the group if it doesn’t exist: 1sudo groupadd ydotoolgroup Add users to the group: 1sudo usermod -aG ydotoolgroup username Replace username with the actual username. Step 2: Verify /dev/uinput PermissionsEnsure that the ydotoold service has the necessary permissions to access /dev/uinput. This typically requires root privileges. Step 3: Test the Command with sudoRun the command directly with sudo to see if it works outside the systemd context: 1sudo /usr/bin/ydotoold --socket-path="/tmp/.ydotool_socket" --socket-own="root:ydotoolgroup" --socket-mode="0660" Step 4: Use chown and chmod ManuallyIf the command still doesn’t work as expected, manually set the ownership and permissions of the socket file to ensure they are correct: Run the command without setting ownership and permissions: 1sudo /usr/bin/ydotoold --socket-path="/tmp/.ydotool_socket" Manually change ownership and permissions of the socket file: 12sudo chown root:ydotoolgroup /tmp/.ydotool_socketsudo chmod 660 /tmp/.ydotool_socket Step 5: Create a Systemd Service FileIf the manual steps work, create or update the systemd service file to reflect the correct setup. Edit the systemd service file: 1sudo nano /etc/systemd/system/ydotoold.service Update the service file content: 12345678910111213141516171819202122[Unit]Description=Starts ydotoold serviceAfter=network.target[Service]Type=simpleRestart=alwaysExecStart=/usr/bin/ydotoold --socket-path="/run/ydotoold/socket"ExecStartPost=/bin/sh -c 'chown root:ydotoolgroup /run/ydotoold/socket && chmod 660 /run/ydotoold/socket'ExecReload=/usr/bin/kill -HUP $MAINPIDKillMode=processTimeoutSec=180# Set the service to run as rootUser=rootGroup=root# Grant the service access to /dev/uinputDeviceAllow=/dev/uinput rw[Install]WantedBy=multi-user.target Reload systemd: 1sudo systemctl daemon-reload Enable and start the service: 12sudo systemctl enable ydotoold.servicesudo systemctl start ydotoold.service Verify the service: 1sudo systemctl status ydotoold.service Explanation: ExecStartPost: This directive ensures that after starting the ydotoold service, the socket file ownership and permissions are explicitly set using chown and chmod. Running as root: Ensures the service has the necessary permissions to access system devices. By manually setting the ownership and permissions in the ExecStartPost step, you can ensure that the socket file is correctly configured after the service starts. This should resolve the issue with UID and GID not being set properly. Here is the service config I used: 1234567891011121314151617# /etc/systemd/system/ydotoold.service[Unit]Description=Starts ydotoold serviceAfter=network.target[Service]Type=simpleRestart=alwaysExecStart=/usr/bin/ydotoold --socket-path="/tmp/.ydotool_socket"ExecStartPost=/bin/sh -c 'chown root:ydotoolgroup /tmp/.ydotool_socket && chmod 660 /tmp/.ydotool_socket'ExecReload=/usr/bin/kill -HUP $MAINPIDKillMode=processTimeoutSec=180[Install]WantedBy=default.target

posts.title: Fix HDMI Monitor Not Showing
posts.excerpt: My HDMI monitor does not work for KDE, try to fix this bug.
posts.text: My HDMI monitor does not work for KDE, try to fix this bug. BackgroundWhen using a HDMI cable to connect my computer with the trash monitor I bought in my home, just failed to transmit signal to the monitor and has no output when using xrandr, when I using KDE Plasma (Wayland). After switching to my win 11 (Dual System), I can connect to the monitor normally so it should not be caused by the computer port or cable or any physical reason. Then back to my Arch, thought it might because of my GPU drivers? Since I have two graphic cards in my Laptop, one AMD graphic card and one Nvidia Geforce 4080 Mobile. Then following the tutorials from Arch Wiki Nvidia and installed one very excellant tool called optimus-manager which is developed to manage the use of hybrid graphic cards. However, it did not work and nothing better. optimus-manager does work, integrated is not workable, should set to hybrid, or the external monitor will fail. Then I thought that it might be Wayland? As most of the materials or tutorials I found are on Xorg. xrandr did not perform the same on wayland, not showing the disconnected devices. Then, thanks to KDE Plasma has both Wayland and X11(Xorg) version, I can switch to the X11 version from SDDM login page (The windows manager). However, still not work, but when running xrandr I can see that xrandr can indeed detect my monitor but just has no signal. Then following this tutorial I can then finally use this command to manually setup the output to my monitor: 1xrandr --output eDP-1 --mode 2560x1600 --pos 0x0 --primary --output HDMI-1-0 --mode 2560x1440 --right-of eDP-1 Where the eDP-1 is the built-in monitor of my laptop and HDMI-1-0 connect to my external monitor. Finally works! Then I can manage them using either xrandr or the Display & Monitor settings of KDE. (KDE Plasma) If the external monitor failed to recover after sleep, which might be caused by Kwin, use this command to restart Kwin session might fix it: 1kwin_wayland --replace & Be careful that it will kill all the applications and need to manually restart the applications. Maybe I should find a more appropriate way? or change to Hyprland to see if there’s any problem about it… My old monitor does not support high refresh rate, only 60Hz works.

posts.text: 只是简单的记录一下安装的步骤。其实还挺简单的。 安装背景新买的机械革命的翼龙15Pro电脑，我确实是受够windows了，想试试别的操作系统。Ubuntu其实也不错，比较成熟，但咱已经用过挺多次了，这次想试试新系统，遇到问题了也是学习的过程嘛。 配置是32G内存+AMD的CPU+Nvidia 4060显卡 + 2T存储2T都用的是长江存储，因为是在拼多多上买的特供版，比标准版加了一块1T的P300存储。新加的硬盘没有原装的性能好，不过也够用了倒是。稍微有点浪费，毕竟咱计划是以Arch作为主力系统使用的。不过也问题不大，数据很多还是存在Win系统盘里，反正Arch也能挂载，就还可以。 安装步骤硬盘准备先把硬盘进行一个清空，用diskgenius进行格式化，确定硬盘变成未使用状态就行 制作启动盘用Rufus和Arch的镜像制作启动U盘，随便找个什么U盘，够大就行。 本来是准备用ventoy做启动盘的，这样可以不用浪费我一个U盘，结果用不了，郁闷。 安装插上U盘之后进入BIOS，从U盘启动放到前边，然后disable掉安全模式，然后启动，就能正常进入Arch的安装界面了，一个经典的CLI 这里就可以按照各种教程来进行正常的安装了，也可以图简单运行archinstall进行prompt安装。 建议选择btrfs文件系统，更新一些并且对分卷和备份很友好安装的时候建议不安装neofetch了，直接安装fastfetch，因为neofetch停止维护了嘛安装的时候选择安装库git fastfetch htop桌面系统可以选择hyprland和KDE两个都装，也可以先只装KDE，hyprland之后手动装也无所谓。总体上没什么坑，各种库可以晚点再自己装也不迟 Grub安装完成之后如果没啥问题就可以了，因为这次是装双系统，然后两个系统安装在不同的硬盘里，而Arch是用Grub进行引导的，所以手动修改一下grub配置，然后重新grub-mkconfig一样就行，把windows的盘的启动选项加进grub.cfg里边就行了，这块直接问GPT就可以。总体上思路很清晰 至于Grub主题配置之类的也直接查教程就行。需要注意的是自己写custom配置的时候，/etc/grub.d/文件夹下的custom选项前边的数字决定了启动项的顺序，可以通过这个调整顺序。也可以安装grub-customizer进行配置，但那个是通过proxy进行配置的，原理不太一样，不过都可以。

posts.path: 2024/07/04/机械革命 蛟龙15K Linux 内置键盘失灵解决(ACPI)_linux 笔记本键盘失灵-CSDN/
posts.excerpt: 机械革命2024款一些笔记本安装Linux后内置键盘失灵但外接键盘正常工作，修复主要通过修改内核解决
posts.text: 机械革命2024款一些笔记本安装Linux后内置键盘失灵但外接键盘正常工作，修复主要通过修改内核解决 https://blog.csdn.net/ZGY_121/article/details/134834265 12345678910111213cat /sys/firmware/acpi/tables/DSDT > dsdt.datiasl -d dsdt.dat# 将PS2K后出现的第一个ActiveLow改为ActiveHighsed -i '/PS2K/,/ActiveLow/ s/ActiveLow/ActiveHigh/1' dsdt.dsl # 将DefinitionBlock版本号加一perl -pe 'if (/DefinitionBlock/) { s/(0x[0-9a-fA-F]+)/sprintf("0x%X",hex($1)+1)/e }' dsdt.dsl > dsdt.dsl iasl dsdt.dslmkdir -p kernel/firmware/acpicp dsdt.aml kernel/firmware/acpifind kernel | cpio -H newc --create > acpi_overridesudo cp acpi_override /bootecho "GRUB_EARLY_INITRD_LINUX_CUSTOM=\"acpi_override\"" >> /etc/default/grubsudo grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg   原因机革笔记本用的主板DSDT 有错误：键盘是下降沿触发，bios里dsdt写成了上升沿触发。 蛟龙16K等一些主板的修复代码已经在6.5以后加入内核。 旧版内核默认以下降沿触发处理，所以没有问题。新内核默认行为改变，键盘无法使用。 下面是两个解决办法，都要使用外接键盘。 修改内核解决1. 查看主板型号1sudo cat /sys/devices/virtual/dmi/id/board_name 2. 修改内核从 6.5 内核起，内核已加入特殊的主板判断代码来强制覆盖acpi行为，使其变为下降沿触发。相关代码的commit: 2d331a6ac在内核源码树中的 drivers/acpi/resource.c 内dmi_system_id irq1_edge_low_force_override变量中。你可以查看一下有无和你主板型号匹配的项，没有就加上，重新编译内核。 具体编译方法虽大致相同，但各个发行版可能会有一些差别，另外我也没用这个方法，就不多赘述。 修改DSDT 并在启动时覆盖根本性的解决方法就是修改bios中的DSDT表了，即官方更新bios修复这个错误。既然官方还没修复，就需要在启动时强制加载新的正确的DSDT。 安装工具包主要是两个 一个是DSDT的编译解码软件 acpica 和cpio 获得原来的DSDT12cat /sys/firmware/acpi/tables/DSDT > dsdt.dat # 获取dsdtiasl -d dsdt.dat # 反编译DSDT成AML文件(.dsl) 修改 dsdt.dsl 找到Device(PS2K) 向下找第一个ActiveLow 改成ActiveHigh 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526Device (PS2K){ Name (_HID, "MSFT0001") // _HID: Hardware ID Name (_CID, EisaId ("PNP0303") /* IBM Enhanced Keyboard (101/102-key, PS/2 Mouse) */) // _CID: Compatible ID Method (_STA, 0, NotSerialized) // _STA: Status { Return (0x0F) } Name (_CRS, ResourceTemplate () // _CRS: Current Resource Settings { IO (Decode16, 0x0060, // Range Minimum 0x0060, // Range Maximum 0x00, // Alignment 0x01, // Length ) IO (Decode16, 0x0064, // Range Minimum 0x0064, // Range Maximum 0x00, // Alignment 0x01, // Length ) IRQ (Edge, ActiveLow, Shared, ) <<=== 目标 {1} }) 给DefinitionBlock 升一个版本(最后一个十六进制数加一) 123DefinitionBlock ("", "DSDT", 2, "ALASKA", "A M I ", 0x01072009)改成DefinitionBlock ("", "DSDT", 2, "ALASKA", "A M I ", 0x0107200A) 编译新的AML文件1iasl dsdt.dsl 最后显示Compilation successful. 0 Errors就算没有问题 使用修改过的DSDT两个方案： 把新dsdt编译进内核 创建一个可以被bootloader加载的CPIO文件 这里使用第二个方法，这两个方法在archwiki里都有详述。 123456mkdir -p kernel/firmware/acpicp dsdt.aml kernel/firmware/acpifind kernel | cpio -H newc --create > acpi_overridesudo cp acpi_override /bootecho "GRUB_EARLY_INITRD_LINUX_CUSTOM=\"acpi_override\"" >> /etc/default/grubsudo grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg 重启看一看修改有没有成功吧 参考 贴吧-蛟龙16K在高版本linux下内置键盘失灵问题 Arch Wiki - DSDT Bilibili-蛟龙16k在高版本linux中键盘失灵解决方案

posts.title: Federated Learning for DDos 比赛 Log
posts.excerpt: 记录比赛实践期间的一些所学和感受，简记学到的知识和理解
posts.text: 记录比赛实践期间的一些所学和感受，简记学到的知识和理解 2020/10/28 配置仓库 数据基础处理 2020/11/8前情回顾： 加入预处理之后直接起飞，准确率直逼100%，主要矛盾转变为过拟合问题 减小模型层数，使用4层感知机，加入dropout层，效果有所提升 调参，，，略吧，，无聊 聚合算法中加入权重：标签丰富度，根据标签丰富度来进行梯度聚合，效果有所提升 加入学习率周期性衰减，效果有所提升 目前最好测试acc为62.7% 之后的测试在改进的基础上进行 测试： layer_num = 4lr=0.001weight_decay = 0.01batchsize=1600n_round_sample=16000max_round=120acc_limit = 95 result: 50轮早停，train：55%，test：57%，未过拟合，效果不错的 75轮早停，train：64%，test：60%，误差范围内吧，还算好 100轮早停，train：68%，test：58%，过拟合，有点严重 实验效果不理想呀，怀疑是学习率的问题？我觉得应该不是模型结构的问题，train在上升，但test并没有提高，只能说明这时候产生了过拟合，test的学习率就没有上去过 测试： layer_num = 4lr=0.001weight_decay = 0.1batchsize=1600n_round_sample=16000max_round=100acc_limit = 95 85轮早停，train：73%，test： 56.68%，过拟合比较严重，原因不明 测试： layer_num = 4lr=0.003weight_decay = 0.1batchsize=1600n_round_sample=16000max_round=100acc_limit = 95 太惨烈，75轮停止，train：67%，test：47%，过拟合严重，看来调学习率似乎也没办法解决？ 测试： layer_num = 4lr=0.001weight_decay = 0.0005batchsize=1600n_round_sample=16000max_round=75acc_limit = 95 大概是比较默认的值了，不抱希望的看看效果 结果也确实没给我惊喜，train 73%，test 54%，十分意料之中 总结一下，经过这些个几轮测试，我觉得之后重复类似的测试也没啥意义了，问题不在这里，过拟合的问题需要寻求别的出路来解决，不是通过换优化器，加正则化能解决的了的我觉得。可能需要有其他的创新性的设计才行。联邦平均算法无疑是一个很优秀的算法。至少在训练集上表现相当优异 测试： layer_num = 4lr=0.01weight_decay = 0.01batchsize=16000n_round_sample=16000max_round=75acc_limit = 95不加标签 47%acc很差，还是要加标签的 2020/11/12换回曾经的那个不加weightdecay的版本，62%的那个。 参数如下： layer_num = 4lr=0.001batchsize=4800n_round_sample=4800max_round=200acc_limit = 95 然后构造了交叉验证集，诡异的事情发生了： 训练集最后90%，交叉验证集87%，说明并没有过拟合，可能： 我的交叉验证集还是数据过于集中，看不出过拟合问题 测试集和训练集的数据分布差异较大，比如测试集里全是那些不容易区分的攻击类型 加入focal loss策略试试看： layer_num = 4lr=0.003batchsize=4800n_round_sample=4800max_round=200acc_limit = 95focal loss = true 最后差别不大，训练集90%，验证集89%

posts.text: ​ 第二次安装PVE加上面的一些群晖、Windows等系统，新买了一张固态。第一次安装没写博客记录，第二次安装记录一下安装过程以及踩的坑。 ​ 教程参考视频：https://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1Br4y1N7VK 本期PVE所有安装资料网盘打包：https://pan.baidu.com/s/1crbYS5-EMAcJIOm6sQyFNA 密码: 4qf0 涉及的链接：PVE官网UltraISO写盘工具DG分区助手MSDN我告诉你 1 准备工作和接线1.1 在进行正式安装之前，需要准备： 一台组装好的主机 显示器一个 键盘一个 路由器一个（也可以使用网线和电脑直连，不过最后横竖是需要连路由器的，不如从最开始就连好好吧实际上是笔记本没网口也没有转接头，没办法和主机直连，只能通过路由器来了，，，） 网线两根（如果直连就只需要一根） 可上网笔记本一台 U盘一个 1.2 安装主机： 路由器上电，WAN口接拨号线，LAN1口和主机相连 将固态插入主机，显示器、键盘和主机相连，主机上电 1.3 配置上网：就配置下密码啊之类的，最后使用笔记本连接路由器，能连上并成功上网就行。然后在主机上ipconfig一下，看看网络信息如下： 2 PVE的安装2.1 制作启动盘先在PVE官网下载对应的iso镜像，然后用UltraISO写进去就行了： 插入U盘，格式化 打开UltraISO，文件->打开->找到PVE的ISO镜像 启动->写入硬盘映像，默认写入就行了 这里遇到的问题1：U盘写有保护，就很烦。WIndows无法格式化，UltraISO也无法写入。最后的解决方案是： 使用DiskGenius软件清除U盘的全部分布，保存修改，注意不要再新建分区了，就让U盘保持空闲状态，然后重新写入。 2.2 安装PVE系统插入启动盘到主机，然后就自动进入了Proxmox VE的安装界面，就一步步走就可以了，其中网络这块，上边我们看到路由器的默认网关是192.168.31.1，所以我们设置我们PVE的ip为固定ip：192.168.31.31，这样之后我们就用连接在路由器上的笔记本，访问https://192.168.31.31:8006/就可以进入到PVE的控制台了。控制台如图： 2.3 进行简单的配置：网络桥接因为我们的主机只有一个网口，所以默认已经配置好了，如果有多个网口，可以点击创建，并新建类似的桥接配置，大致如图： 3 安装群晖NAS系统3.1 创建虚拟环境由于我们的主机的配置是：cpu4核8线程，16GB内存，512G固态，安装完PVE之后还有三百来G固态空闲。所以可以奢侈一点配置 如图进行相应的配置（不需要太谨慎，之后还可以在这个hardware和option里边更改配置）： 3.2 配置黑群晖启动之后要进行黑群晖的引导安装： 先将最开始创建的硬盘Hard Disk删除，detach，然后remove，（上图是配置好的，不要看Hard disk部分） 随便使用什么SSH连接工具（mobaXterm等）连接到PVE，然后上传资料包中的img2kvm，NAS引导+固件/3617xs/synoboot.img两个文件到PVE 输入指令： 12chmod +x img2kvm./img2kvm synoboot.img 100 vm-100-disk-1 # 这里的100就是创建的虚拟机的id，在pve的下拉列表中可以看到 进入的PVE浏览器后台，可以看到一个未使用的磁盘，选中，添加，然后将总线设备更改为SATA，其他默认 返回，找到选项 options，将引导顺序（boot order）双击进入，将我们新添加的这块调整到第一启动项并设置启用。 之后我们再给NAS添加一块硬盘： 再返回到Hardware，选择add->Hard disk，选择Storage并设置大小就好 返回控制台，启动 3.3 连接到群晖连接这里其实不太好连接，有几种方法： 如果NAS可以上网的话，可以使用在线方法查询（但反正我没成功过）： 下载群晖助手，安装好之后启动就会默认检测当前局域网内的群晖设备（我猜是检测局域网内的），一般来说就只能检测到一个设备，也就是我们刚装好的设备 如果可以登录到路由器后台的话，可以通过查看ip地址，看看哪个是刚刚加进去的，就是我们的群晖的ip 总之就是为了得到群晖设备的ip地址，得到ip之后在浏览器上输入ip 端口5000（其实不输入端口好像也行），就可以进入群晖的后台了。如果使用群晖助手，双击也可以。 3.3 配置黑群晖进入控制台之后，应该是一个如图的配置界面： 然后选择设置，选择手动安装，选择浏览，找到NAS引导+固件/3617xs/DSM....pat，之后启动安装 安装完成之后进行管理员配置即可： 之后简单配置一下，群晖账号那里跳过就行了，之后就进入到主界面中： 可以打开Package Center，如果NAS能上网的话，各种套件已经可以访问到了。 3.4 添加存储 找到菜单中的Storage Manager，进入 在Storage Pool中create，配置默认就行，Raid那里可以设置成Basic，之后完成 在Volume（存储空间）中create，选择刚新建的存储池，然后默认配置就好，最后完成 之后回到NAS主界面，找到控制面板，找到共享文件夹，新增，然后自己配置一下就行了，最后别忘了设置读写权限。 最后我们就可以用我们本机windows访问共享文件夹了，在文件浏览框中输入\\192.168.31.xxx/，输入用户名和密码就可以访问了共享文件夹了！ 3.5 添加硬盘到PVE 参考博客：https://wangxingcs.com/2020/0910/1442/ https://blog.csdn.net/xiaobo060/article/details/105928108/ 懒得写这个了。。。。。网上教程比较多，随便来就行，，，思路就是先把硬盘挂载到PVE，说白了还是Linux上，然后写/etc/fstab文件实现自动挂载。然后再到PVE的浏览器控制台data center-> storage -> add 就行了 要注意的一点是，对于大容量硬盘来说，fdisk命令不能分超过2T空间的区，所以这时候需要使用parted工具来进行分区，然后格式化的时候要注意一下inode的数量不要过多，不然很浪费空间，具体可以看博客 大容量硬盘分区和格式化参考博客：https://blog.csdn.net/Richardlygo/article/details/87867042 4 安装windows 10系统 参考： https://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1Wh411k7g5?from=search&seid=16913643997894754399 这篇配置的windows系统使用了半直通配置，稍微复杂一点，但性能更好一些。 4.1 准备镜像准备windows 10 的ISO镜像文件（msdn，官网，或者随便哪里都行，只要能下到windows10的镜像文件） 还需要下载virtIO驱动 之后到PVE的浏览器控制台，pve节点下的local(pve)这里，上传ISO Images，上传到PVE中： 4.2 创建虚拟器还是一样的配置，create VM，然后配置，这里有几个地方需要改动： OS这里选择使用镜像安装，系统选择windows 版本选10。 然后在system里边勾选上Qemu Agent（用于远程桌面的） 硬盘那里推荐用SCSI 网络那里的模型选用VirtIO半连通 这样就创建完成了 之后新增一个光驱，IDE就好，然后添加virtIO驱动的镜像，检查一下boot order是否勾选上了win10的镜像，然后启动虚拟机 4.3 win10安装流程一路进去，自定义安装，然后到了你想将windows安装在哪里，这里没有检测出任何一个磁盘： 点击加载驱动程序 然后浏览，选择virtIO的CD driver，进入找vioscsi/win10/amd64，确定，下一步，应该就可以成功识别出驱动器了。然后新建分区，大概长这样： 之后按步骤一步一步安装就行了，最后启动windows进入到桌面。 4.4 配置驱动打开设备管理器，可以看到： 然后选择打感叹号的那三个，先配网：更新驱动程序->浏览电脑查找驱动->选择virtIO driver进入，找到NetKVM/w10/amd64，安装驱动就好。 之后两个PCI设备也是一样，在浏览查找驱动的时候可以直接选择virtIO driver，也就是D: 这个目录，然后直接安装，它就会查找当前目录下可用的驱动程序。（适用于不知道驱动是哪个的情况） 4.5 配置远程桌面进入文件管理器，到virtIO driver中，找到guest-agent，安装x86-64版 之后关机重启，就可以在PVE管理后台中win10节点的summary里边看到IP地址了 然后可以在虚拟机中开启远程桌面服务，设置可访问的用户及权限，就可以使用其他windows系统进行远程桌面访问了。 5 内网穿透配置 参考： https://blog.csdn.net/weixin_33393017/article/details/112882580 实际测试效果：ZeroTier的速度太缓慢了，用来做SSH连接传一些命令还可以，但移动桌面什么的还是想都别想了 内网穿透使用的是ZeroTier平台，原理大概就是借用这个平台搭建虚拟局域网。ZeroTier的使用就从略了，直接注册，创建网络，然后再使用客户端连接就好。windows客户端很简单，下载安装，然后join Network就行了。 需要注意的是： 每新添加一个设备到局域网，都需要访问ZeroTier的控制台将此设备enable，这样才能正常连接，算是一个保险措施吧。 安装ZeroTier之后，使用ipconfig 或者 ifconfig 等，可以查看到有个虚拟网卡，并配置有ip： 这样就算是加入到局域网中了，在同一个局域网中的设备是互相可见的。 主要是在NAS中配置出现的问题比较多： Docker端的Zerotier好像无法正常使用，按照网上的教程没有成功 使用ZeroTier官网给的下载链接下载的时候要下载对应的版本的，需要先在群晖中开通SSH连接，然后使用SSH连接到群晖，用命令uname -ar，可以查看到最后的版本信息： 这就代表此DSM是Bromolow版本的，就需要下载对于版本的套件（有NAS版块，Synology就是） 经过测试，只有1.4.0版本的套件可以用，1.4.1版本的套件会遇到缺少文件的bug 下载完毕后，进入群辉“套件中心”，点击手动安装，然后选择我们刚才下载的*.spk文件完成安装。 安装完成之后可以open，但一般会遇到没有内容，join点了没反应的问题。解决方案： 使用SSH连接到群晖的Shell sudo zerotier-cli join ID，ID就是申请到的网络的id号，正常返回结果是200 join OK 此时再打开群晖的套件，就显示正常了。 返回到Zerotier的官网的管理界面，授予新加入的设备权限即可： 也可以使用sudo -i 进行提权 注意，如果中途有报错说tun找不到的话（我就遇到了。。。），需要手动安装tun模块，这个模块在内核代码中有，所以只需要对应的操作就好了，详细百度。 6 PVE使用优化6.1 增加CPU温度显示6.1.1 安装软件 使用SSH连接到PVE的命令行（也可以在PVE的后台的shell中操作），下载插件sensors：apt install lm-sensors 安装完成之后使用sensors-detect进行相应的配置操作，一路yes应该就可以了。 之后输入命令sensors，就可以看到硬件的温度信息 6.1.2 配置文件首先先备份之后要更改的两个文件： 12cp /usr/share/perl5/PVE/API2/Nodes.pm /usr/share/perl5/PVE/API2/Nodes.pm.bakcp /usr/share/pve-manager/js/pvemanagerlib.js /usr/share/pve-manager/js/pvemanagerlib.js.bak 编辑第一个文件： vi /usr/share/perl5/PVE/API2/Nodes.pm 增加一行代码： 12345678910111213141516171819202122232425$res->{ksm} = { # 可以使用这句话定位到此位置 vi: /res->{ksm} shared => $meminfo->{memshared},};$res->{swap} = { free => $meminfo->{swapfree}, total => $meminfo->{swaptotal}, used => $meminfo->{swapused},};$res->{pveversion} = PVE::pvecfg::package() . "/" . PVE::pvecfg::version_text();$res->{temperature} = `sensors`; # 此处增加这行代码，获取 CPU 和 主板 的温度my $dinfo = df('/', 1); # output is bytes$res->{rootfs} = { total => $dinfo->{blocks}, avail => $dinfo->{bavail}, used => $dinfo->{used}, free => $dinfo->{blocks} - $dinfo->{used},};return $res; 编辑第二个文件： vi /usr/share/pve-manager/js/pvemanagerlib.js 增加一段代码： 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536... { itemId: 'version', colspan: 2, printBar: false, title: gettext('PVE Manager Version'), # 可以此段代码搜索到指定位置 textField: 'pveversion', value: '' }, { itemId: 'temperature', colspan: 2, printBar: false, title: gettext('CPU Temperature'), textField: 'temperature', renderer: function(value){ const c0 = value.match(/Core 0.*?\+([\d\.]+)?/)[1]; const c1 = value.match(/Core 1.*?\+([\d\.]+)?/)[1]; const c2 = value.match(/Core 2.*?\+([\d\.]+)?/)[1]; const c3 = value.match(/Core 3.*?\+([\d\.]+)?/)[1]; return `Core0: ${c0}℃ | Core1: ${c1}℃ | Core2: ${c2}℃ | Core3: ${c3}℃` }} ], updateTitle: function() { var me = this; var uptime = Proxmox.Utils.render_uptime(me.getRecordValue('uptime')); me.setTitle(me.pveSelNode.data.node + ' (' + gettext('Uptime') + ': ' + uptime + ')'); }});... 之后进行重启控制台即可systemctl restart pveproxy 如果没有刷新，则清除缓存之后重试，或者ctrl+F5强制刷新 6.2 换用高速源安装升级一些linux必要工具先备份原本的配置文件：mv /etc/apt/sources.list /etc/apt/sources.list.bak 之后创建一份新的配置文件：vi /etc/apt/sources.list 添加如下内容： 12345678deb https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian/ buster main non-free contribdeb https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian/ buster-updates main non-free contribdeb https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian/ buster-backports main non-free contribdeb-src https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian/ buster main non-free contribdeb-src https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian/ buster-updates main non-free contribdeb-src https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian/ buster-backports main non-free contribdeb https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian-security/ buster/updates main non-free contribdeb-src https://mirrors.aliyun.com/debian-security/ buster/updates main non-free contrib 之后执行apt update更新 PVE默认安装的nano，反正我是不太会用，但安装的vim版本太低，所以我们安装一些包： 123apt install vim # 安装vimapt install net-tools # 使用ifconfigapt install iputils-ping # 使用ping 参考：https://www.cnblogs.com/surplus/p/14391801.html

posts.title: VScode终端中文乱码解决
posts.excerpt: VScode的终端调用的是cmd或者powershell，不巧这两个shell默认的中文编码方式都是GBK，但我们经常用的是UTF8格式，所以经常会遇到中文乱码，那么如何解决这个问题呢？
posts.text: VScode的终端调用的是cmd或者powershell，不巧这两个shell默认的中文编码方式都是GBK，但我们经常用的是UTF8格式，所以经常会遇到中文乱码，那么如何解决这个问题呢？ 思路由于电脑默认的是powershell，这里以powershell为例： 只要不怕麻烦，每次打开终端都使用命令chcp 65001，手动将编码方式改到utf-8就好，但这样太麻烦了，所以思路就是在打开终端时自动执行这条命令 之前其实vscode是支持直接使用shellArg属性来定义的，很多博客也是这么来的，但不巧，我下载的最新版的VScode把它给取消了 ，，，一个头两个大，那就需要更奇妙一些的配置了 老版本的配置如果是1.56之前版本的VScode，很简单的配置如下： 在VSCode中通过打开“文件”–“首选项”–“设置”, 然后在setting.json中设置, 把下面三行复制到里面: 123456{ "editor.fontSize": 18, "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": ["/K chcp 65001 >nul"] //这句如果无法执行，就换成"-NoExit", "/c" ,"chcp 65001" "terminal.integrated.fontFamily": "Lucida Console",} /K chcp 65001 >nul的含义是在运行cmd的时候将编码设置为65001; nul是避免在控制台输出修改编码的信息，否则会输出active code page: 65001;同时，赠送两个彩蛋，例如:editor.fontSize: 20(修改字体大小为 20);terminal.integrated.fontFamily:”Courier New”(字体修改为 “Courier New”).这个可以根据自己的需求填写，当然如果不需要的话，可以不写。 >nul可能是个坑，反正我配置了之后提示out-file之类的问题，不过就一行输出就放弃吧，删了就行了 1.56版本VScode之后的配置由于新版的VScode不支持shellArgs这个参数了，强行设置会报错 所以需要用到比较高级一点的配置方式如下： 123456789101112131415{ "terminal.integrated.profiles.windows": { "PowerShell": { "source": "PowerShell", "icon": "terminal-powershell", "args": ["-NoLogo","-NoExit", "/c" ,"chcp 65001"], //在终端启动时使用chcp命令将编码格式改变为UTF-8 }, "Command Prompt": { "path": "${env:windir}\\System32\\cmd.exe", "icon": "terminal-cmd", "args": ["-NoLogo","-NoExit" ,"chcp 65001"] }, }, "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.windows": "PowerShell" // 必不可少！要不然上边的都没用} 这里使用了profiles，实际上就是自定义shell的参数等等。-NoLogo参数是指在启动的时候不显示版权信息（加不加都行） 参数可以通过powershell -help查看，还是比较清楚的 然后defaultProfile参数必须要，缺省的话VScode会默认使用系统配置的powershell（woc这个地方卡了我好久好久好久，一直在纠结为啥配置了之后不生效）。这一条也可以通过UI界面来配置如图： 写在最后有一说一，还是学到了一些东西的，对VScode编辑器也有了更全面的了解，但是还是号麻烦啊，而且耽误事儿/笑哭 由于刚好赶上升级，然后升级之后就出现了这个问题，导致几乎所有的教程的方法都无法使用了，最后是在github上vscode的issue上找到的灵感，才最终成功配置，另外，很怪的是我配置好了之后，发现博客的评论区居然有昨天某位大佬给出的解答，和我的一模一样。可惜了怎么不专门开个帖子呢。害我自己琢磨了两个多小时，，，， reference： 永久解决VSCode终端中文乱码问题_ityanger的技术栈-CSDN博客_vscode终端中文乱码 （关注评论区） Upgraded to version 1.56.0… Issues with terminal/Powershell · Issue #123066 · microsoft/vscode · GitHub PowerShell 的命令行启动参数（可用于执行命令、传参或进行环境配置）_walterlv - 吕毅-CSDN博客_powershell 参数

posts.text: 《联邦学习》是杨强、刘洋等人编著的面向数据安全和隐私保护的机器学习的综述性的书，整体上不是很具体，但是能对联邦学习有一个比较大体的了解 作者：杨强刘洋程勇康焱陈天健于涵 1.引言介绍人工智能的挑战以及联邦学习的分类和发展 1.1 人工智能面临的挑战 数据量庞大难以达到，通常得到的数据规模小，信息不全（需要打标）难以桥接的数据孤岛 数据所有权，用户隐私和数据安全的关注度不断提高，法律法规，在不同组织间收集数据和分享数据将变得越来越难，某些高度敏感的数据也不能无限制计算和使用。 如何在条条框框更多，解决数据碎片化和数据隔离的问题 将数据联合起来协同训练会导致数据失去掌控，整合后带来的性能赠一不好分配，分配效果不透明，加剧数据碎片化和孤岛分布 物联网和边缘计算，大数据分布在许多方面。eg：自动驾驶汽车在本地要处理信息，并且和其他的汽车和计算中心协同工作 =》 如何安全有效的实现模型在多个地点间的更新和共享 1.2 联邦学习概述 寻求一种方法，训练机器模型 | 不必所有数据集中到一个中心 单独训练一个模型 | 每个数据源 >>> 各模型彼此交流沟通 | 设计交换模型信息的过程 => 保护隐私 >>> 模型聚合得到全局模型 => 仿佛数据源整合 1.2.1 联邦学习的定义 联邦学习 = { 模型训练，模型推理 } 模型训练阶段：模型相关信息共享 | 数据不共享 | 交换过程不会泄露隐私 模型推理阶段：协作预测 >>> 公平的价值分配机制 => 分配协同模型获得的收益 特点： 有多个参与方 | 持有数据 数据不离开所有者 模型信息在各方之间传输交换 | 加密 | 无法根据模型推测数据 性能充分逼近理想模型（集中数据训练的模型） 中央协调方；可以有也可以不涉及 挑战： 通信链路：不稳定；速度慢 样本数量 or 分布 ：不均衡 => 联邦模型产生偏差 容易遭到恶意攻击： 破坏性的模型更新信息 => 可用性降低 等 1.2.2 联邦学习的分类 联邦学习 ={ 横向联邦学习，纵向联邦学习，迁移联邦学习} 数据组成：样本ID: ，特征空间 ，数据标签空间 ， 横向联邦学习： 按样本划分的联邦学习 重叠的数据特征较多 eg：不同地区的银行 数据特征取交集，数据ID取并集 纵向联邦学习： 按特征划分的联邦学习 重叠的数据较多 ID eg：一家银行一家电商，客户群体上有很大交集，提供不同服务 数据取交集，特征取并集 联邦迁移学习 重叠都比较少的时候 1.3 联邦学习的发展1.3.1 联邦学习的研究 Secureboost，提升纵向联邦学习安全性 | 无性能损失 | 隐私保护 | 提升树系统架构 联邦学习的脆弱性，很容易被投毒 联邦学习和强化学习 多任务学习 vs 联邦学习的统计学难题 1.3.2 开源平台 Federated AI Technology Enabler （FATE）微众银行 | 开源项目 | 安全计算框架 | 联邦学习平台 TensorFlow Federated （TFF） 开源框架 TensorFlow-Encrypted 搭建在tensorflow顶层的python包，用于实验 => 机器学习方式|面向隐私保护 coMind 开源平台 | 联邦平均算法的实现 <= 关键组件 搭建在tensorflow顶层并提供api Horovod 由Uber创立，基于开放的消息传输接口（Message Passing Interface MPI） OpenMined/PySyft，提供两种方法 | 隐私保护 { 联邦学习 ， 差分隐私 } 1.3.3 联邦学习标准化开展IEEE P3652.1 Federated Machine Learning Working Group 1.3.4 联邦人工智能生态系统FedAI Ecosystem 开源技术 标准和指导方针 多方共识机制 垂直行业的应用 2. 隐私、安全及机器学习介绍背景知识 | 机器学习相关 | 面向隐私保护 { 机器学习技术， 数据分析 } 2.1 面向隐私保护的机器学习Privac-Preserving Machine Learning，PPML 系统 由个人，团体或机构自行决定何时、如何以及在多大程度上将有关他们的信息传达给他人 ── Alan F.Westin 信息安全的主要思想是控制对个人信息的收集和处理的过程 2.2 面向隐私保护的机器学习与安全机器学习 安全威胁 攻击模式 防御方法 PPML 隐私性 重构攻击 安全多方计算 机密性 模型反演攻击 同态加密 成员推断攻击 差分隐私 安全机器学习 完整性 投毒攻击 防御精馏 可用性 对抗攻击 对抗训练 询问攻击 正则化 ​

posts.text: ​ KTH BNSS 课设，基于OpenWRT搭建VPN服务的部分，WireGuard比较顺利，而OpenVPN却困难重重，不过最后还是给配好了，中间遇到的问题和经验记录如下 1. 安装OpenVPN并进行基础的配置1.1 环境信息OpenWRT version：19.07 1.2 安装OpenVPN到OpenWRT这里主要是参考了官网的教程进行软件的安装，然后就是经典读脚本理解配置文件时间，主要参考官网的脚本和教程。但从这里开始就遇到问题了，一方面是版本的问题，另一方面就真的是官方的锅了。有很多问题解决的也是碰巧。 ####### 此处描述安装流程并附上reference 1.3 使用官方脚本创建configure文件########## 此处详细描述使用官方脚本的流程 ########## 此处详细描述由于版本不同造成的问题，并附上debug的方法 ########## 此处详细描述最后的解决方法 1.4 尝试使用图形化管理方式并描述遇到的问题######### 此处描述图形化管理居然无法显示使用uci配置的instance的问题（太tmd蠢了），并描述是如何通过端口冲突发现的，并如何解决的 2. 进行其他的配置除了configure，还要配置firewall 2.1 配置firewall3. 解决无法连接外网的问题重头戏，这块实在太扯淡了，详细描述这傻逼事情 3.1 问题描述描述可以建立连接但是ping不通也无法上网的问题 3.2 debug方式描述debug的尝试 3.3 最终解决描述最终是怎么解决的，也是比较扯淡，主要是两点： 不仅要重启openvpn，也要重启network （介绍怎么发现的，10.0.4.0 => 无法ping通10.0.2.1, => 修改network=>重启network，居然可以连通了=>但ip是10.0.1.2,=>尝试变回10.0.4.2,=>无法连通=>复现=>发现必须重启网络服务才能连通） configure里边的server项要设置成包含在内网内的部分，同时DNS要设置成内网的网关，否则无法连通

posts.title: WSL玩耍记录
posts.excerpt: ​ 在windows10上边安装了WSL，记录一下是怎么整的，还是有点好玩的。
posts.text: ​ 在windows10上边安装了WSL，记录一下是怎么整的，还是有点好玩的。 1.安装WSL安装WSL主要参考microsoft的官方指南，因为都说WSL2好用，所以就选择用WSL2，这玩意儿装还需要扩展kernel。 主要流程大致： Enable the Windows Subsystem for Linux Enable Virtual Machine feature Download the Linux kernel update package，double click and run Set WSL 2 as your default version Install your Linux distribution of choice(through Microsoft store, Ubuntu) 复杂嘛倒也不复杂，但是在Microsoft Store下distribution的时候，老给我报错说windows update给关了不让装（因为之前用联想的工具把自动更新给关了，还得重新给打开，然后再装） 2.配置WSL配置WSL就是纯粹的娱乐环节啦，主要参考了以下几篇博客： 安装图形界面：https://www.cxyzjd.com/article/tomatt77/109596590 安装一些常用工具： https://www.jianshu.com/p/bc38ed12da1d 2.1 安装图形界面这里主要查到有这么几种方案： 使用windows远程连接访问 使用VNC远程连接 ✓使用RDP远程连接 使用软件绘制图形界面 Xming： Xserver+VcXsrv： 最后选了用RDP进行远程连接的方案，主要是说这个沉浸式体验比较流畅，反正我有俩显示器，一个用来显示也挺OK的。VNC和RDP原理上不太一样，但RDP是微软自家的东西，咱就图省事儿直接用了。最后结果还OK。 2.2 安装一些常用工具这里主要安装一些我可能会比较常用的，比如zsh，vscode之类的。主要参考以下一些博客 微软官方指南：https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/setup/environment 一些小工具：https://www.jianshu.com/p/bc38ed12da1d 懒得解释了，先传着，如果有需要记录的再补充吧。。。。

posts.title: 俄航出国经验总结
posts.excerpt: ​ 2021.8.7俄航飞瑞典求学，一路上还算比较顺利地到达了KTH，总结一下经验
posts.text: ​ 2021.8.7俄航飞瑞典求学，一路上还算比较顺利地到达了KTH，总结一下经验 1. 订机票首先提前一两个月订机票，我订的还算早，订到了比较便宜的机票。这次因为疫情，飞国外的话比较麻烦。最赚的是香港飞的，从蛇口码头坐船到香港国际机场，免入境直接起飞。比较便宜，而且时间好，可以赶上8.2接机。 俄航算是比较便宜的，但是时间上不太友好。一个是因为太早了（早上7:10飞），要提前来上海蹲着。一个是8.7有点不早不晚的，白交半个月房租。 订机票的时候还要考虑到航班取消的问题，疫情期间有时候航班会被迫取消，这样可能会打乱之后的计划。不过俄航每周就飞一天，两班飞机，很稳定没取消过。 最后要提前了解入境政策和中转国家过境政策。莫斯科是24小时内免入境转机，但丹麦好像就需要过境签，需要提前准备好。 订机票可以在官网订，也可以在飞猪、携程等平台上订，不过要看清除机票来源，避免被坑（所以果然还是官网订比较稳妥，就是麻烦了点）。 2. 起飞前2.1 booking code订完机票之后会收到邮件，在附件里边可以看到自己的booking code，也就是那个六位大写字母的号码，这个之后值机的时候会用到，比较重要。至于航站楼之类的，其实不太需要提前关注，因为有可能会变化，以值机的时候的信息为准。 2.2 关于核酸 俄航目前的规定是需要72小时的英文核算检测报告。所以要么做好然后赶飞机，要么提前一天来上海做。 需要提前查一下在哪些位置可以开中英文核算检测报告，以及： 是否需要预约，在哪里预约 一周中的哪几天工作，每天的工作时间 结果多久能出，以及费用问题 这些信息一般网上能查到，但最好打电话确认一下，像我在之江检测所做的，虽然说要预约，但可以到了现场填信息约，也不麻烦。然后最便宜的标准检测80元，说是12-24小时出结果，但其实一般上午去做了下午4点多就出结果可以去取了，完全没必要加急（当时医生就说了，上午做一般下午就能取），但要注意他们的工作时间。人不多，一般不用排队。 最后有一点可以确认一下，就是俄航对检测方法有要求，可以确认一下，一般都是常规荧光检测什么的。 取的纸质的报告单一定不要弄丢了，最好和护照放一起。 2.3 住宿最后综合以上情况，我是选择提前两天到上海，8.7号早上的飞机，我是8.5快中午做的核酸报告。为了方便取报告，选择的住宿的位置也是离检测所的位置比较近的。 因为俄航是一大早从上海浦东国际机场起飞，而机场离市区相当tmd远，如果要在上海玩一下的话，不建议在机场附近住。机场附近的酒店都有送机巴士，但时间一般都是早上4:00之后，比较晚。 所以凌晨三点多去机场，基本上只有打车去一种选择了（机场大厅并不舒服，强烈不建议去那挨一晚上，难受死） 我是使用高德打车，30公里左右吧到机场，大概90元 2.4 值机俄航提前24小时可以在线值机，主要是选座位。主要用到booking code，提前在知乎之类的地方了解一下选座位怎么选以及哪些座位对长途飞行比较友好（虽然这些座位一般都抢不到或者不让选）。 2.5 机场流程把自己和一堆行李折腾到机场之后就比较简单了，首先找辆行李车把箱子啊包啥的都往上边一堆（这个车车在机场门外边，找不到问一下，一定要整一辆）。然后推着进机场，要过一道安检。 之后找到值机和行李托运的柜台（因为在线值机过了，PVG的值机和行李托运好像在一起），问一下工作人员俄罗斯航空的值机柜台在哪里，过去排队就行了。 我当时去得有点晚，提前2.5h到的，光在这里就排了tmd1.5h，强烈建议至少提前3h，最好提前3.5h到，免得在那里带一堆行李站半天。 这里会有人查核酸，提前准备好护照、居留卡、核酸证明就行了。等排队排到了就带着大包小包去办理，整个流程不太复杂，按部就班来就行。需要注意：1. 行李不要超重 2. 可以带一个登机箱或者包（10kg），再背一个随身小包（5kg），尺寸查的不严，重量其实也不太严/笑哭，但最好别挑战。 行李最好用那种专门的行李打包带包一下，实在不行用保鲜膜或者胶带包一圈也行，主要防止有人私自打开你的行李塞些baisefenmo什么的。 行李托运办完之后就按部就班地过边检、安检，之后去对应的登机口侯着就行了。 在办完行李托运之后还可以满机场乱跑，行动不受限，和亲戚道别啥的可以先办完托运再说 过海关不能拍照 安检的时候会让你把笔记本、键盘、平板等电子设备都拿出来单独过安检，所以，整理了也白整理（但行李托运好像没这问题，不过行李托运也不能托运这些就是了）。乖乖拿出来过了安检再重新装包里吧 3. 飞行期间飞行期间没太多需要注意的，一些tips： 俄罗斯小姐姐真好看 俄罗斯小姐姐真好看 俄罗斯小姐姐真好看 带一双一次性拖鞋飞机上穿，更舒服一点 包放头顶上，一个小包可以放脚下，不过会压缩本就不大的休息空间，所以建议把证件、手机之类的随身，其他的都扔头顶 英语交流，加手势，一般都能交流 第一程飞机会有两餐，所以乘机那天可以不吃早饭 第二程飞机会有一餐，但由于疫情，最好留着到瑞典了再吃 第一程吃饭上厕所都OK，第二程就憋住，不吃不喝不拉不撒，戴好口罩和手套（手套好像没人会查，但最好戴吧）等防疫用品，和小姐姐说不要水，thanks 4. 转机只需要在moscow转一次飞机，比较简单，跟着路牌（有中文）走就行了，过安检也比较简单，不需要憨皮地掏电子产品，但是要摘手表和皮带，注意下别裤子掉了就行。 轶闻：因为摘皮带用了一小会儿，皮带就和下一个妹子的箱子放一个篮子里过安检，然后那妹子的箱子没过，要排队检查，，，导致我提着裤子等了半天拿皮带。。。。。 可以去服务台问一下候机在哪个口，这个有可能会变化。（当然，也有显示屏会显示） 5. 下飞机来KTH下飞机之后走过长长的通道去领行李，之后去过海关。之后就顺利下飞机了，想办法来KTH就行。 建议方法：express买票，坐车到CentralStation，然后转地铁14号线，坐moroby central方向，到tekniska hogskolan下，直走出站就能看到KTH的校标了。

posts.text: ​ 尝试了一下Jupyter lab，各种问题还是有点多的，感觉除了导出的格式比较多，其他方面不比vscode好用，这里简单记录一下 1. 安装Jupyter Lab首先就是安装，因为默认只有conda的base环境中有Jupyter lab，其他环境需要自己安装，但这个也比较简单，直接命令安装就行： conda install jupyterlab 然后就可以直接使用jupyter lab命令打开了 2. 快捷打开要打开jupyter lab非得用conda有点太麻烦了，所以这里用一点小技巧： 找到默认的jupyter notebook的快捷方式：复制一个到桌面上 修改名称位jupyter lab，修改起始位置，用来标定最开始的起始页面 修改目标为：D:\softwares\anaconda3\python.exe D:\softwares\anaconda3\cwp.py D:\softwares\anaconda3\envs\python3_learn_ML D:\softwares\anaconda3\envs\python3_learn_ML\python.exe D:\softwares\anaconda3\envs\python3_learn_ML\Scripts\jupyter-lab-script.py 注意这里只修改最后两项改成了我的自定义环境中的python路径和scripts路径，这样才能正常启动自定义环境中的而不是base环境中的jupyter lab，自己摸索出来的，目前没找到网上和我一样干的 大功告成，双击运行一下试试吧 3. 其他一些配置这样已经可以正常使用了，但是要让他更好用还是需要一些其他配置，但这样的各种各样的配置就很麻烦了，在网上也能找到解决方案，就懒得写到博客里了，遇到什么问题解决什么问题就行了。有空再补全吧。 现在的问题是lsp代码自动补全插件很慢很慢，慢到影响我使用了肯定不行，然后导入依旧不支持pdf导出，不过可以导出成markdown也不错，所以现在还行，vscode日常写一些脚本，然后再到lab里导出成markdown吧，然后再typora编辑导出成pdf，有点怪，不过用习惯了应该还行/笑死
